OpenCV3 has issues linking with -lopencv_imgcodecs. mxnet uses pkgconfig to find the opencv libraries, and opencv generates an opencv.pc, or opencv-3.2.0-dev.pc file somewhere for this. Copy the opencv.pc file into /usr/lib/pkgconfig/ and mxnet should be able to find the opencv binaries.

@piiswrong: yes, all loss functions we use in Mathematica must respect this, so I did add handling for this. See [this](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/5834/files#diff-5574eb3b2aa10440c134dbe9c1599dc2R206), and check if its correct.

Ok, guys the problem is that libmxnet.dll  dependent **cudnn64_5.dll,**  i.e. you need to download 5 version of the cudnn (not the last version).
@jiajiechen, Going forward can you please create separate PRs for new APIs that you add? lets keep review-correction cycle to only the APIs that you initially submit PR for.

I'm closing my own issue. I got it to work in the following way:
model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(...)
layer_weights <- model$arg.params
model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(..., arg.params=layer_weights)
@mli if this looks good can you merge it? I am almost done with the test script for this and hope to add a Jenkins job by end of today or tomorrow.
@piiswrong how about we set the default dtype for variable as float32?

Hi @salemmohammed 

I'm also starting to read mxnet now, so my understanding will have lots of mistakes but we can learn together.

I think http://mxnet.io/architecture/note_engine.html is a very good documentation.
The codes for creating/killing threads are under src/engine folder

From what I'm understanding is after executor optimized the graph, we will push ops to engine in topo order.
There are 3 engines: 
1.naive 
2.threaded pool 
3.threaded per device

threaded pool engine is create a common thread pool for all devices and all workers are consuming tasks from the blocking queue.

threaded per device engine is creating thread pool per device. 
I'm not sure the purpose of creating this engine, my guess is the execution time is not similar across different devices, so it's better to dispatch similar job in the same queue to increase throughput.
Hope someone better understand can explain...

Thanks

[12:13:24] d:\program files (x86)\jenkins\workspace\mxnet\mxnet\dmlc-core\include\dmlc\./logging.h:300: [12:13:24] D:\Program Files (x86)\Jenkins\workspace\mxnet\mxnet\nnvm\include\nnvm/tuple.h:446: Check failed: dim == static_cast<int>(ndim()) (4 vs. 5) dimension do not match target dimension 4 vs 5
[12:13:24] d:\program files (x86)\jenkins\workspace\mxnet\mxnet\dmlc-core\include\dmlc\./logging.h:300: [12:13:24] d:\program files (x86)\jenkins\workspace\mxnet\mxnet\src\engine\./threaded_engine.h:329: [12:13:24] D:\Program Files (x86)\Jenkins\workspace\mxnet\mxnet\nnvm\include\nnvm/tuple.h:446: Check failed: dim == static_cast<int>(ndim()) (4 vs. 5) dimension do not match target dimension 4 vs 5
An fatal error occurred in asynchronous engine operation. If you do not know what caused this error, you can try set environment variable MXNET_ENGINE_TYPE to NaiveEngine and run with debugger (i.e. gdb). This will force all operations to be synchronous and backtrace will give you the series of calls that lead to this error. Remember to set MXNET_ENGINE_TYPE back to empty after debugging.
I would automatically set it to num physical cpu.

Are you suggesting that we have an API function like `MXSetNumOMPThreads`, but also default `omp_set_num_threads` to the number of physical cores when MXNet starts?

One thing we have noticed: for things like unrolled RNN's, the CPU usage increases hugely when going from 1 OMP thread to 4, but the speed doesn't increase much (sometimes it decreases). So we would like control at runtime of the thread number.

This sounds like a bug we should fix...

but yeah a MXSetNumOMPThreads API is fine.
Ok, great. Will make a PR.
I do want to add support for variable length inputs (it currently only supports variable length labels). But I will do that in a separate PR, so this can be merged now.

@madjam Fixed it

I would like to point to some findings I had with using MKL and @zhreshold's implementation of Depthwise Separable Convolutions training on CIFAR-10 on a c4.8xlarge (Intel Xeon E5-2666 v3 CPU)

**Vanilla Resnet**
```
MKL Build:20170209
INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [20]	Speed: 100.25 samples/sec	Train-accuracy=0.111235
INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [40]	Speed: 121.83 samples/sec	Train-accuracy=0.186719
INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [60]	Speed: 137.36 samples/sec	Train-accuracy=0.203906
INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [80]	Speed: 155.15 samples/sec	Train-accuracy=0.219922
INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [100]	Speed: 147.89 samples/sec	Train-accuracy=0.244531
```

**Resnet w/ Depthwise Separable Convolutions**
```
MKL Build:20170209
INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [20]	Speed: 73.22 samples/sec	Train-accuracy=0.117188
INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [40]	Speed: 138.27 samples/sec	Train-accuracy=0.170313
INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [60]	Speed: 132.47 samples/sec	Train-accuracy=0.206250
INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [80]	Speed: 138.98 samples/sec	Train-accuracy=0.242578
INFO:root:Epoch[0] Batch [100]	Speed: 156.11 samples/sec	Train-accuracy=0.250781
```
So we can see not too much changes once MKL is introduced. 

Without MKL turned out, the results were more exaggerated (~2.5x speed-up). However, without using MKL, throughput is 10x slower than with it on.

Thank you for your contribution.

On the first point, thank you for your notice about this. It was introduced when we process nnvm 0.9.3 changes as in commit https://github.com/precedenceguo/mx-rcnn/commit/410f089ddec6abd6afa453c869e81c36020b8c64
As a consequence, it is possible that resnet results cannot be fully reproduced to my experiments on v0.9.1.
Would you please consider change it back to "prefix in name" instead of changing the config for "name.startswith(prefix)"?

On the second point, I am afraid that "fix_gamma=True" is set for "bn_data" because of the pretrained ResNet-v2 model is trained this way c.f. https://github.com/tornadomeet/ResNet/blob/master/symbol_resnet.py

On the result of improvement, I think by changing to "prefix in name", better performance is possible.

@wguo68 @NiklasTreutner @II-Matto A new patch (#6033) that makes cpp-package support MSVC will be soon merged, which makes it easier to create and build project in MSVC with cpp-package.

@Soonhwan-Kwon: MXNet now has a native ctc loss op: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/5834

It uses the WarpCTC implementation, so it shouldn't be any slower than using the plugin. It also returns the actual CTC loss, so you don't need to calculate this with custom Python code.

@piiswrong: we are very interested in dynamic graph construction direction MXNet is going in. A question: how flexible (compared to pytorch) is this? For example, can complicated NLP examples be implemented (like https://devblogs.nvidia.com/parallelforall/recursive-neural-networks-pytorch/)?
